(1) If at any time during the holding of a license granted under this chapter, it should appear that the licensee has violated the provisions of this chapter, or the laws of the state or any federal laws, or if it should appear that the application contained known false information, or if it appears necessary for the public safety, health and welfare, the police chief of the city, his assistants who are acting under his authority, or any officially designated license inspector may request the commission to suspend or revoke the license to sell or consume any alcoholic beverages within the city. (2) Reserved. (3) The commission shall hold a hearing on such request for a revocation or suspension and after such hearing, the commission may revoke or suspend said license or place said licensee on probation. (b) Action by the commission. The commission shall have full power and authority to revoke, refuse to renew, suspend or place on probation any licensee to sell or consume alcoholic beverages for violation of this chapter, or of the state or federal laws, or when said commission shall determine, after five days' notice and hearing that the operation of the licensed business is detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the public. For the purpose of this section it shall be sufficient if notice is mailed, giving the time and place of the hearing by United States Certified Mail at the address of the licensee as shown in the application. (1986 Code, § 9-3-30; Ord. No. 2011-23, 1-9-2012) Sec. 6-31. - Taxation. In addition to the annual license fees required, there is hereby levied and imposed an excise tax which shall be paid to the city, as provided by Georgia Laws, on all malt beverages sold by each wholesale dealer within the area of the city. (1986 Code, § 9-3-31) Sec. 6-32. - Method of tax payment. Tax shall be paid to the city by each wholesale dealer on all malt beverages sold within the city not later than the 10th day of each month, based upon the units of beverage sold during the previous calendar month by said wholesalers to retailers in the city. (1986 Code, § 9-3-32) Sec. 6-33. - Payment of tax, report. The wholesale dealer shall keep true and correct records of all sales and shipments and shall render a sworn statement of the name accompanying the monthly report to the city clerk, and said report shall show the exact quantities of malt beverages, by size and type of container and the amount of excise tax collected. (1986 Code, § 9-3-33) Sec. 6-34. - City's right of audit. The city shall have the right to audit, and to require production of records from each wholesaler supplying retailers in the area of the city, and also from each retailer so supplied. (1986 Code, § 9-3-34) Sec. 6-35. - Failure to make a timely report and payment; penalty. The failure to make a timely report and remittance of aforesaid taxes shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the total amount due, in addition to the amount due; and additionally if said report is not filed or if said taxes are not remitted and paid within 30 days from the date that the same are due, the city shall have the right to suspend and/or revoke any wholesale license, and further to prohibit said wholesaler from making any deliveries of any type whatsoever within the area of the city. (1986 Code, § 9-3-35) Sec. 6-36. - Sale prohibited when tax not paid. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell at retail or otherwise dispense beverages within the city on which the tax required in this article has not been paid to the wholesaler or distributor or to the city. (1986 Code, § 9-3-36) Secs. 6-37—6-50. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - WINE
Sec. 6-51. - Definitions. (a) Unless the context demands otherwise, the words and terms used in this article shall have the same definition and meaning as state law where used in O.C.G.A. tit. 5A (Alcoholic Beverage). (b) "Business location" shall mean the location or proposed location of a retail wine outlet. (1986 Code, § 9-3-51) Sec. 6-52. - License required. (a) A separate license shall be required for each wine outlet, and a separate application shall be made for each outlet. (b) No license shall be transferable or assignable. (c) Immediately upon the sale or closing of an outlet, it shall be the duty of the licensee to surrender the license to the city. (1986 Code, § 9-3-52) Sec. 6-53. - Classification of licenses; license fees. License under this article shall be classified as follows: (1) Retail which shall permit only the sale of wine in packages at retail. (2) Wholesale-wholesale wine distributor, which shall permit only the sale of wine at wholesale. The amount of the license fee for each class shall be set as set forth in the license schedule in section 6-62. (1986 Code, § 9-3-53) Sec. 6-54. - Application and qualifications for license. Application for a retail package wine license shall be the same as, and in accordance with the requirements applicable to the sale of malt beverages by the package at retail, and all provisions in this chapter pertaining to the application and qualifications for a malt beverage license, including sections 6-3 through 6-9 shall be enforced in the sale of wine. All regulations controlling the sale of malt beverages shall also be applicable to the sale of wine as if fully set out as a separate section hereunder. (Note: Wholesalers delivering wine on prior orders are not required to have a wine license when business is not located in city). It is the intention of this article that wine be sold either in conjunction with a qualified and licensed retail malt beverage outlet under the sale standards and restrictions as are applicable to retail malt beverage outlets, or if the licensee so desires that wine may be sold at a qualified licensed wine outlet which does not sell malt beverages; however, under all circumstances wine outlets shall be under the same standards and restrictions as are applicable to malt beverage outlets under this chapter. (1986 Code, § 9-3-54) Sec. 6-55. - Taxation. (a) In addition to the annual retail wine license fee required, there is hereby levied an excise tax computed as prescribed by Georgia laws. (b) The tax shall be paid to the city clerk, by each wholesale distributor, on all wine sold to the retailers in the city, no later than the tenth day of each month based upon the units of wine sold during the previous calendar month by said wholesalers to retailers in the city. (c) Each wholesale distributor shall furnish to the city clerk a summary of all purchase invoices for wine sold to each retailer in the city on or before the tenth day of each month following such purchases. Said invoices shall show the amount of excise tax paid. (d) The city shall have the right to audit, and to require production of records from each wholesaler, supplying retailers in the city and from each retailer so applied. (1986 Code, § 9-3-55) Secs. 6-56—6-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ADDITIONAL RULES AND REGULATIONS
Sec. 6-61. - Business hours of outlets. Retail dealers and licensees for malt beverages, wine, or distilled spirits shall not engage in the sale of same except between the hours beginning 7:00 a.m. through 1:00 a.m. on Monday through Friday, and 7:00 a.m. until 12:00 a.m. midnight on Saturday, provided however, there shall be no sales permitted on Sundays, or Christmas Day, or any other day on which they are required to be closed by the laws of the State of Georgia. (1986 Code, § 9-3-61; Ord. No. 2005-06, 4-11-2005) Sec. 6-62. - Annual license fees. (a) The annual license fee for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling malt beverages at wholesale within the area of the city shall be $100.00. (b) The annual license fee for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling wine at wholesale within the area of the city shall be $100.00. (c) The annual license fee for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling distilled spirits at wholesale within the area of the city shall be $100.00. (d) The annual license fee for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling malt beverages and/or wine at retail within the area of the city shall be $500.00. (e) No license shall be issued for less than the calendar year as herein provided, and in case of revocation or surrender of any license before the expiration of such calendar year, the holder thereof shall not be entitled to receive any refund whatsoever. (f) The aforesaid license fees herein set shall not be pro-rated for any portion of a year and shall remain the full amount when said calendar year expires with regard to the time the application is made. (g) The mayor and council of the city shall have the authority to set the annual license fees contained in this section by resolution. (1986 Code, § 9-3-62; Ord. No. 2005-06, 4-11-2005) Sec. 6-63. - Visibility and lighting of outlets. No license shall be granted to a retailer under any provision or section of this chapter unless the front entrance to the outlet is clearly visible from a public street, road or highway, and the front of said outlet shall have a minimum window at least three feet by four feet, and no screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or things which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of the outlet shall be permitted in the window or upon the doors of any retail outlet. Each retail outlet shall be so lighted that the interior of the store or premises is visible day or night and all parking areas adjacent to or used in connection with said business shall be fully lighted and unobstructed. (1986 Code, § 9-3-63) Sec. 6-64. - No consumption on premises. The retail license authorized hereunder are for retail sales in package only and there shall be no consumption on the premises of any outlet of any malt beverages or wine, except those outlets provided for in section 6-62(d). (1986 Code, § 9-3-64) Sec. 6-65. - Intoxicated persons. No malt beverage nor wine shall be sold to any intoxicated person, nor shall any intoxicated person be allowed to remain upon the premises of any outlet. (1986 Code, § 9-3-65) Sec. 6-66. - Sale to and/or possession by minors. No malt beverages nor wine shall be sold to a minor under any conditions whatsoever. A minor for the purposes of this chapter shall be considered to be any person under 21 years of age. Unless the officer has reasonable cause to believe such person is intoxicated, a law enforcement officer may arrest a person under 21 years of age who purchases or knowingly possesses alcoholic beverages by issuing a citation which shall enumerate the specific charges against the person and either the date upon which the person is to appear to answer the charges or notation that the person will be later notified of the date upon which the person is to appear and answer the charges. The law enforcement officer arresting a person by the issuance of a citation may require such person to deposit a driver's license with the arresting officer to assure the appearance of such person to answer the charges against him. (reference, section 5A-9901.1, (d) and (c) of State Alcoholic Beverage Code). (1986 Code, § 9-3-66) Sec. 6-67. - Employees, drinking on premises. No employees of any outlet shall work in said outlet while intoxicated and no employee shall drink any malt beverages, wine, or alcoholic beverages whatsoever while working and employed in any outlet. (1986 Code, § 9-3-67) Sec. 6-68. - Minors on premises of retail store selling malt beverages or wine. Minors shall not be allowed to congregate or loiter on the premises of any retail store outlet selling malt beverages or wine. (1986 Code, § 9-3-68) Sec. 6-69. - Advertising, commission approval required. The commission shall have authority to establish uniform rules and regulations regarding advertising. All advertising must be approved by the commission prior to use. No other signs which will be visible from the exterior of the building shall be permitted. (1986 Code, § 9-3-69) Sec. 6-70. - Licenses, posting. All licenses required under this chapter must be posted in a conspicuous place within the outlet, and if said license is not so posted the outlet shall not be authorized to continue in business until the same shall be so posted. (1986 Code, § 9-3-70) Sec. 6-71. - Posting of ordinance. At all times the retail licensee under this chapter must post within the place of business a copy of this ordinance in a conspicuous place within the outlet. (1986 Code, § 9-3-71) Sec. 6-72. - Compliance with rules and regulations of health authorities. All retail licensee's under this chapter are hereby required to comply with all rules and regulations and requirements of the county board of health, state board of health and any and all other state, federal and local authorized public health authorities. (1986 Code, § 9-3-72) Sec. 6-73. - Retail licenses, categories. Retail licenses under this article shall be of three categories as follows: (1) Retail store licenses. A retail store license as defined herein shall be one issued to a business whose primary function is the sale of food, medicines and related merchandise and the sale of malt/wine beverages at retail is incidental to the operation thereof. All malt/wine beverages must be located within the interior of any such outlet, shall be sacked in containers at the check-out counter of such outlet at time of sale, and no such beverages shall be opened or consumed, either inside or outside the premises. (2) Private clubs which are affiliated with a nationally chartered organization, either service, athletic or charitable, with a minimum of 200 members, occupying no less than 5,000 square feet, and provided further that the sale of malt beverage or wine shall not be the major part of said business, but only incidental with it's operation. (3) Other retail commercial buildings which meet the specifications and rules of the commission. (1986 Code, § 9-3-73) Sec. 6-74. - License fees, time to pay. All license fees required under this chapter shall be paid prior to the issuance of any license. (1986 Code, § 9-3-74) Sec. 6-75. - Wines authorized under this chapter. For the purpose of this chapter wine which is authorized hereunder is that wine which is authorized to be legally sold and distributed in counties which have not authorized the legal sale of distilled spirits and spirituous liquors as defined by the laws of the state. (1986 Code, § 9-3-75) Sec. 6-76. - Possession for the purpose of sale or resale. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to sell or possess for the purpose of sale or resale of any malt/wine beverages where such does not have a license from the city to sell or possess for sale or resale such beverages. It shall be presumed, as a matter of law, that any person having located on his premises more than 1,440 fluid ounces of malt beverage or five gallons of wine shall have the same in his possession for the purpose of resale. (1986 Code, § 9-3-76) Sec. 6-77. - Receipt of any delivery to retail licensee. Malt beverages and/or wine shall be received at or delivered to the premises of the retail licensee by no other means than by a conveyance owned and operated by a wholesale dealer with a permit from the city to make deliveries in said transportation of malt/wine beverages by any other means shall be grounds for a revocation of a wholesale permit or license. Receipt of malt/wine beverages by any other means by a retail licensee shall be grounds for revocation of a retail license. (1986 Code, § 9-3-77) Sec. 6-78. - Licenses, nontransferable. No licenses granted under this chapter shall be transferable from one person to another, nor shall the same be transferable from one outlet (location) to another. (1986 Code, § 9-3-78) Sec. 6-79. - Manager of outlet; requirement for registration of manager. If the person to whom any license under this chapter is issued does not personally manage the outlet, the name of the manager of the outlet must always be registered with the commission, and the manager of the outlet must meet all the requirements of a person to whom a license could be granted hereunder. If such licensed outlet is not managed directly by the holder of the license, or there is no manager registered as provided thereunder who meets all the requirements hereunder, then said license may be suspended or revoked. If such a manager is changed, the holder of the license must notify the city clerk no later than ten days from the date of the change of such manager and all information required hereunder with regard to managers shall also be furnished to said clerk at said time. (1986 Code, § 9-3-79; Ord. No. 2011-23, 1-9-2012) Secs. 6-80—6-90. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE COMMISSION
Sec. 6-91. - Establishment of malt beverage and wine commission. The council shall appoint a five-member "malt and wine beverage control commission," independent of the commission, each member of which shall serve until replaced by a majority vote of the council. The council, by majority vote, shall designate one of the five members of the malt and wine beverage control commission as the "presiding officer." The presiding officer shall moderate all meetings of the malt and wine beverage control commission during his term of office, but shall have no executive functions or powers greater than the other members of the malt and wine beverage control commission. The presiding officer may be removed at any time by majority vote of the city council. A quorum of three members of the commission shall be necessary for the transaction of any business. (1986 Code, § 9-3-91; Ord. No. 95-03, § 1.5, 3-27-1995) Editor's note— Ord. No. 95-03, § 1.5, adopted March 27, 1995, changed the title of § 6-91 from "Established; composition" to "Establishment of malt beverage and wine commission." Sec. 6-92. - Powers and duties. The alcoholic beverage commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities as are granted to them by the terms and provisions of this entire chapter including but not limited to all other provisions of state law as may be applicable to the sale of alcoholic beverages. It is the intent of this chapter that all of the duties, responsibilities, and decisions pertaining to the granting of licenses, revoking the same, suspending same, and the like, and all other matters pertaining to the control of alcoholic beverages as provided under this chapter shall be vested in said commission as herein provided. The alcoholic beverage commission shall furnish a copy of the issuance of any license, license renewal, suspension, revocation, appeals, minutes of alcoholic beverage commission meetings and such other documents as the alcoholic beverage commission may designate to the mayor and council, city clerk, city manager, city attorney, chief of police and code of enforcement department. It shall be the responsibility of the city manager to ensure the timely distribution of all documents and information herein above set forth. The city manager shall upon the filing of any appeal, suspension or revocation of an alcoholic beverage license or any decision concerning same, document the date and time of the filing thereof and shall furnish a copy of same instanter to the alcoholic beverage commission, city attorney, chief of police and code enforcement department. (1986 Code, § 9-3-92; Ord. No. 2005-06, 4-11-2005; Ord. No. 2006-23, 11-27-2006) Secs. 6-93—6-100. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - ON-PREMISES CONSUMPTION
Sec. 6-101—6-120. - Reserved. Sec. 6-121. - License issuance authorized. Licenses for the sale of malt beverages, wine and distilled spirits for on-premises consumption shall be a mere grant or privilege during the term of said license, subject to all the terms and conditions imposed by this chapter and division, and any other related laws of the State of Georgia, the Charter, and this Code. A license for on-premises consumption may be issued as provided in this chapter. (Ord. No. 2002-03, 3-25-2002; Ord. No. 2005-06, 4-11-2005) Sec. 6-122. - Conflicts. All sections and divisions of chapter 6 are herein made applicable to division 5, to the extent that same are not in conflict with any section in division 5. (Ord. No. 2002-03, 3-25-2002) Sec. 6-123. - License. An applicant for on-premises consumption shall be required to submit an application as is set forth in this chapter and pursuant to the requirements of O.C.G.A., § 3-3-2. An application for a license may be denied upon the grounds as is set forth in section 6-28. (Ord. No. 2002-03, 3-25-2002) Sec. 6-124. - Laws and regulations adopted. The State laws and regulations relating to the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages in Georgia, as revised and proclamated by the general assembly of the state and by the state revenue department, and especially as they relate to wholesale, retail package sales, and retail sales for consumption on the premises, are hereby incorporated into and made a part of this chapter as if fully set out herein. (Ord. No. 2002-03, 3-25-2002) Sec. 6-125. - Business application. Applicants possessing all of the necessary qualifications for the issuance of a license for the sale of malt beverages, wine and/or distilled spirits for consumption on the premises shall be required to possess a city business license and the appropriate state, county, and municipal health department certificates for the sale and service of food and beverages to the general public with a seating capacity of not less than 125 people. It shall be further required of applicants as a condition to the issuance of a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises, that said sale of alcoholic beverages shall be ancillary to the primary business of the serving of food which shall consist of at least 80 percent of the gross receipts of the business. A condition of the issuance of a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises is that the food sales of the licensee shall account for the majority of the gross revenue of said business. The licensee shall be required at all reasonable times and places as designated by the city manager and/or the alcoholic beverage commission, to produce financial records and documentation as may be required by the city manager and or the alcoholic beverage commission. The requirements contained herein shall not apply to a wine or growler sample license contained in section 6-134. (Ord. No. 2002-03, 3-25-2002; Ord. No. 2005-06, 4-11-2005; Ord. No. 2011-23, 1-9-2012) Sec. 6-126. - Hours of sales of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on premises. Licensees for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises shall be authorized to sale same as is authorized and permitted in section 6-61. (Ord. No. 2002-03, 3-25-2002) Sec. 6-127. - License fees as hereinafter set forth shall not be pro-rated for any portion of a calendar year. A license shall be issued for not less than a calendar year, unless hereinafter provided. (a) The annual license fee for the privilege of selling malt beverages for consumption on premises shall be $500.00. (b) The annual license fee for the privilege of selling wine for consumption on premises shall be $500.00. (c) The annual license fee for the privilege of selling distilled spirits for consumption on-premises shall be $2,000.00 for the year 2005, and $4,000.00 commencing January 1, 2006. (d) Special event license fee for the privilege of selling alcoholic beverages for consumption at event shall be $350.00. (e) The mayor and council shall be authorized to set the schedule of license fees contained in this section and section 6-128 by resolution. (f) Sample license fee shall be $200.00. (Ord. No. 2002-03, 3-25-2002; Ord. No. 2005-06, 4-11-2005; Ord. No. 2011-23, 1-9-2012) Sec. 6-128. - Taxation/wholesaler and dealer collection. In addition to the annual license fees required, there is hereby levied and imposed an excise tax in accordance with the O.C.G.A. § 3-4-130, that shall be paid to the city in the amount of three percent of the charge to the public for the beverages. (Ord. No. 2005-06, 4-11-2005) Sec. 6-129. - Special event license. Notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary, the alcoholic beverage commission shall have authority to issue a special event license for the sale of alcoholic beverages. Conditioned upon such terms and provisions as may be set forth upon the issuance of said special event permit, provided however, that said issuance does not conflict with state laws. (Ord. No. 2005-06, 4-11-2005; Ord. No. 2007-13, 5-14-07) Sec. 6-130. - Special event—Definition. Special event shall mean any organized activity sponsored by a business, organization, corporation, association or individual having as its purpose entertainment, recreation, and or education, such as a festival or celebration, foot or vehicle race, parade or march, rally or assembly which takes place on a public street, sidewalk or right-of-way, or occurs on private property and impacts government services on public right-of-ways or streets. Special events shall not include an occasional family celebration, parties, wedding anniversary and private gatherings. (Ord. No. 2007-13, 5-14-07) Sec. 6-131. - Applications. The applicant for any special event license shall be responsible for the provision of police and sanitation services within the boundaries of the event and for the grant of the license privilege the director of public utilities, director of public works, the chief of police, the fire chief and the code enforcement officer shall approve the impacted government services. In addition each department of the government reviewing an application may recommend in writing certain recommendations or restrictions as deemed necessary to facilitate the event, to comply with other laws or regulations and or to insure the safety, health and welfare of the community. Applicants shall further be responsible for compliance with all laws including but not limited to underage consumption. (Ord. No. 2007-13, 5-14-07) Sec. 6-132. - Indemnification of city/liability. As a condition of issuance, the approved applicant agrees to indemnify, hold harmless, release and defined the city, city officials, and officers and employees from and against any and all liability, loss, suits, claims, damages, cost, judgments and expenses including attorney's fees and cost of litigation which in whole or in part result from, or arise out of, or are claim to result from or to arise out of any acts, negligence, errors, or omissions of applicant, applicant's employees, representatives, contractors, subcontractors, agents whatsoever and without limitations. (Ord. No. 2007-13, 5-14-07) Sec. 6-133. - Termination of activities. The safety, health, welfare and good order of all citizens and the community shall be first and foremost and every special event shall be conducted in such a manner as to comport with this standard. The chief of police or fire chief or their representative or their respective designee, may terminate any activity, whether a part of or the entire event, which does not meet the community standard. Upon notification to the applicant to cease any activity, the activity so ordered to be ceased shall immediately be terminated and the continuous of said unauthorized activity shall be unlawful and the applicant could be subject thereto criminal and civil sanctions. (Ord. No. 2007-13, 5-14-07) Sec. 6-134. - Wine or growler sample for wine or beer brews on tap to go in sealed containers. (a) A licensee for the sale of package malt beverages may be issued a license to give or sell samples of tap beer brews for growler's or wine to go in sealed containers (subsection 6-127(f)). (b) A growler or wine sample shall not exceed one ounce nor shall an individual be offered more than three samples within a 24-hour period. (c) The intent of the sample license is to permit the customers to lawfully taste a sample of the tap brew or wine so as to make a selection of the brew or wine to be sold for carryout in a sealed container. (Ord. No. 2011-23, 1-9-2012)

div.head: Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; offenses in places of public amusement, § 54-4. State Law reference— Exchange of free replay for anything of value unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(c); Amusement Ride Safety Act, O.C.G.A. § 34-12-1 et seq.; authority to license, tax and regulate billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-2; state licensing of coin-operated amusement machines, O.C.G.A. § 48-17-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 10-1. - Liability insurance required for operators of certain amusement devices. All persons shall, prior to operating an amusement device where human beings are conveyed, obtain a permit from the city. Upon requesting a permit, the applicant must show evidence of personal liability insurance in the amount of $500,000.00 for each person and $1,000,000.00 for each accident plus $100,000.00 property damages. The applicant shall provide the name of a person domiciled in the county as agent for service of process. (Code 1986, § 9-1-5) Secs. 10-2—10-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT
Sec. 10-31. - Provisions saved from repeal. The ordinance adopted October 11, 1993, on the subject of adult entertainment is not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the city.

div.head: Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority to regulate animals, § 1.13(1). Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 46; RA residential-agricultural district, app. A, art. XIV. State Law reference— Dogfighting, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-37; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; sale of dog meat for human consumption prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-160; fish, O.C.G.A. § 27-4-30 et seq.; wild animals, O.C.G.A. § 27-5-4 et seq.; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; animal bites, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-4; inoculation of dogs and cats against rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-6; rabies inoculation tags, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-6; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; livestock running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq.; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to run at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7; authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 14-1. - Abandonment prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave, dump or abandon any animal within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1986, § 11-3-1) Sec. 14-2. - Livestock prohibited. No fowls, horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats, swine or other like animals shall be kept or allowed to remain upon any private property or premises located within the city; neither shall any fowls, horses, mules, cattle, sheep, goats, swine or any such animals belonging to the owners or occupants of any residence or property located within the city be allowed to roam at large on the streets or highways or alleys of the city. (Code 1986, § 11-3-2) Sec. 14-3. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dog includes female as well as male dogs. Nuisance means but is not limited to defecation, urination, disturbing the peace, destroying private property, attacking persons or other animals, emitting noxious or offensive odors, or emitting noxious or offensive sounds and noises. Officer means any police officer of the city and/or any officer or employee of the county rabies control department. Owner means any person owning, having an interest, or having control or custody or possession of any dog. Running at large means off the premises of the owner or custodian of the dog and not under the immediate control of the owner or custodian. Public road means any street, road, highway or way, including the full width of the right-of-way, open to the use of the public for vehicular travel. Vicious dog means any dog which shall bite or in any other manner attack or attempt to attack any person within the corporate limits of the city; except that any dog which bites, attacks or attempts to attack any person unlawfully on its owner's or keeper's premises or which is provoked to attack shall not be deemed to be a vicious dog. (Code 1986, § 11-3-11) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 14-4. - Restraint of dogs. The owner, keeper or custodian of any dog within the corporate limits of the city shall be responsible for keeping it from becoming a nuisance or from endangering or injuring any other persons or property, and shall further keep the dog under control at all times. (Code 1986, § 11-3-12) Sec. 14-5. - Running at large prohibited. No person owning, having an interest in, harboring, or having charge, care, control, custody or possession of any dog shall cause or permit the dog to be off the premises of its owner unless such dog is securely confined by a strong leash, securely and continuously held by a competent person owning, having an interest in, harboring, or having charge, care, control, custody or possession of the dog, or unless the dog is confined within a vehicle. (Code 1986, § 11-3-13) Sec. 14-6. - Barking dogs. It is declared to be a nuisance, and no person shall keep, maintain or permit any dog within the municipal boundaries of the city which by any sound, bark or cry shall interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property by any person. A dog must bark for a 15-minute period before the dog will be considered a nuisance. (Code 1986, § 11-3-14) Sec. 14-7. - Cleanliness of premises where dogs are kept. Every person owning or occupying premises where any dog is kept shall keep the premises in which the dog is kept in a clean and sanitary condition. (Code 1986, § 11-3-15) Sec. 14-8. - Administration. Police officers of the city and/or any officer or employee of the county rabies control department shall have the duty and the power to enforce all sections of this chapter and may institute proceedings in the municipal court on behalf of the city against any person violating any provisions or terms of this chapter. (Code 1986, § 11-3-18) Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. Sec. 14-9. - Impoundment; killing of certain dogs. (a) It shall be the duty of any officer or employee of the county rabies control department to impound in the county pound all dogs found running at large. Impoundment fees, redemption and disposition of animals shall be in accordance with the county pound regulations. (b) If in the attempt to seize a dog it becomes impossible to secure it with the hands, the rabies control officer, upon being convinced that the seizure of the dog is necessary to the public welfare and safety, may, within his discretion, destroy the dog by shooting it, provided he is close enough to the dog to kill it humanely and far enough removed from any bystander so that no lives may be imperiled by the act. (Code 1986, § 11-3-19) Sec. 14-10. - Interference with officers. Any person who shall hinder, molest or interfere with a police officer or county rabies control officer in the performance of any duty provided by this chapter, or any person who shall use a tag on a dog for which it was not issued, and any person who owns or harbors a dog without complying with the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the penalties of section 14-11. (Code 1986, § 11-3-20) Sec. 14-11. - Penalties. Any person who is convicted of a violation of any section or subsection of this chapter shall be punished as provided in Charter section 4.13. However, no person shall be charged or convicted of keeping or maintaining a nuisance unless and until the city warrant for violation of this chapter has been signed by the complainant. (Code 1986, § 11-3-21) Secs. 14-12—14-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DANGEROUS DOGS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.
Sec. 14-41. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Animal control board means a board consisting of three persons, two of which shall be appointed by the city and one of which shall be appointed by the county board of commissioners. The board shall hold hearings to hear and determine certain matters provided for in this article. Animal control officer means an employee of the city whose duties specifically include enforcement of the provisions of this article. Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority: (1) Inflicts a severe injury on a human being without provocation on public or private property. (2) Aggressively bites, attacks or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification. Dog control officer means the chief of police of the city and employees of the animal control division acting under his supervision and control. Governing authority means the city council. Local government means the city. Owner means any natural person or any legal entity, including but not limited to a corporation, partnership, firm or trust, owning, possessing, harboring, keeping or having custody or control of a dog or cat within the territorial boundaries of the city. Potentially dangerous dog means any dog that without provocation bites a human being on public or private property. Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog while on the owner's property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top; and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. Rabies control officer means an employee of the county board of health, whose specific duties include enforcement of the rabies control rules and regulations of the county. Records of an appropriate authority means records of any state, county or municipal law enforcement agency; records of any county or municipal animal control agency; records of any county board of health; records of any federal, state or local court; or records maintained by the dog control officer pursuant to this article and state law. Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or a physical injury that results in death. Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 14-42. - Exemptions. A dog that inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties shall not be a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this article. A dog shall not be a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this article if the injury inflicted by the dog was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort, or was tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog, or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused or assaulted the dog, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. Sec. 14-43. - Investigation of reports; classification of dogs as dangerous or potentially dangerous. Upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within a dog control officer's jurisdiction from a law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer or county board of health, the dog control officer shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. Whenever the dog control officer classifies a dog as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, or reclassifies a potentially dangerous dog as a dangerous dog, notice shall be given the dog's owner in writing by certified mail to the owner's last known address of such classification or reclassification. Such notice shall be complete upon its mailing. Sec. 14-44. - Notice to owner. The notice mailed to the owner as provided in section 14-43 shall meet the following requirements: (1) The notice shall be in writing and mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address. (2) The notice shall include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. (3) The notice shall be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog. The hearing shall be held before the animal control board. (4) The notice shall state that if a hearing is not requested and received by the office of the dog control officer within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes under this article on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing. (5) The notice shall include a form to request a hearing before the animal control board and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering the form to the office of the dog control officer. Sec. 14-45. - Hearing. When the animal control officer receives a request for a hearing as provided in section 14-44, he shall schedule such hearing within 30 days after receiving the request. The animal control officer shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of the date, time and place of the hearing; and such notice shall be mailed to the dog owner at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence; and in addition thereto the animal control board shall receive such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the animal control board may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify or overrule the dog control officer's classification of the dog. Sec. 14-46. - Determination after hearing. Within ten days after the date of the hearing provided for in this article, the animal control board shall notify the owner in writing by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify that it is effective on the third day following the date shown on the letter notice. Sec. 14-47. - Enforcement procedures. As applied to the owners of potentially dangerous dogs, the procedures provided for in this article must be carried out as a necessary condition for the enforcement of the provisions of this article against such owners. As applied to the owners of dangerous dogs, the procedures provided for in this article shall not be an essential element of any crime provided for in this article. Sec. 14-48. - Registration. (a) It is unlawful for an owner to have or possess in this city a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration issued in accordance with the provisions of this section. (b) Subject to the additional requirements of section 14-49 for dangerous dogs, the dog control officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog if the owner presents to the dog control officer or if the dog control officer finds sufficient evidence of: (1) A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog. (2) The posting of the premises where the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property and containing a symbol designed to inform children of the presence of a dangerous dog. (3) Payment to the city of a fee in the amount set out in the schedule of fees to defray the cost of administering and enforcing this section. Sec. 14-49. - Insurance, bond requirements. In addition to the requirements of section 14-48, the owner of a dangerous dog shall present to the dog control officer evidence of: (1) A policy of insurance in the amount of at least $15,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to transact business within the state insuring the owner of the dog against liability for any personal injuries inflicted by the dangerous dog; or (2) A surety bond in the amount of $15,000.00 or more issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in this state payable to any person injured by the dangerous dog. Sec. 14-50. - Scope of certificate issuance. Issuance of a certificate of registration or the renewal of a certificate of registration by the city does not warrant or guarantee that the requirements of the law of the state or as specified in sections 14-48 and 14-49 are maintained by the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog on a continuous basis following the date of the issuance of the initial certificate of registration or following the date of any annual renewal of such certificate. Sec. 14-51. - Renewal of registration certificate. Certificates of registration of dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs shall be renewed on an annual basis. At the time of the annual renewal of a certificate of registration, a dog control officer shall require evidence from the owner or make such investigation as may be necessary to verify that the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is continuing to be confined in a proper enclosure and that the owner is continuing to comply with other provisions of this article. Sec. 14-52. - Situations requiring report to officer. The owner of a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked a human, has died, or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall provide the dog control officer with the name, address and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. Sec. 14-53. - Moving to or from this jurisdiction. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if the owner is moving from the dog control officer's jurisdiction. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the state shall register the dog as required in this article within 30 days after becoming a resident. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves from one jurisdiction to another within the state shall register the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog in the new jurisdiction within ten days after becoming a resident. Sec. 14-54. - Possession without certificate; keeping in violation of conditions of certificate. (a) It shall be unlawful for an owner to have or possess within the city a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration. (b) It shall be unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration but will prevent it from biting any person. (c) It shall be unlawful for an owner of a potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the restraint of a responsible person. Sec. 14-55. - Confiscation; notice, redemption, disposition. (a) A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or by another person authorized by the dog control officer if the: (1) Owner of the dog does not secure the liability insurance or bond required by section 14-49; (2) Dog is not validly registered as required by section 14-48; (3) Dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (4) Dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 14-54. (b) A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog if the dog is: (1) Not validly registered as required by section 14-48; (2) Not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (3) Outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 14-54. (c) Any dog that has been confiscated under the provisions of subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this article and upon payment of reasonable confiscation cost as fixed by the fee schedule approved by the governing authority and as the schedule is amended. Notice of confiscation under this article shall be given to the owner in writing by mail at his last known address. The notice shall state that if the owner has not complied with the provisions of this article within 20 days from the date shown on the notice, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and a humane manner; however, no dog shall be destroyed under this section unless it has been held a full 20 days exclusive of the date shown on the notice. Sec. 14-56. - Authority of dog control officer. A dog control officer is authorized to make whatever inquiry is deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. The dog control officer shall cooperate with other dog control officers and law enforcement agencies of other local governments in enforcing the provisions of this article and the laws of the state. Sec. 14-57. - Construction of provisions. (a) The provisions of this article are in addition to and supplementary of any existing law of the state and are to be construed to be consistent with state law. (b) It is the intention of this article to at least meet the minimum standards and requirements for the control of dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs in accordance with the Official Code of Georgia, and this article shall be construed to be amended by operation of law at any section where this article does not meet that minimum standard of the state law. Sec. 14-58. - Liability for damages. It is the intent of the city council that the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall be solely liable for any injury to or death of a person caused by such dog. Under no circumstances shall the city or any employee or official of the city who enforces or fails to enforce the provisions of this article be held liable for any damages to any person who suffers an injury inflicted by a dog that has been identified as being a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, or by a dog that has been reported to the proper authorities as being a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, or by a dog that the city has failed to identify as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, or by a dog which has been identified as being a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog but has not been kept or restrained in the manner described in section 14-48, or by a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog whose owner has not maintained insurance coverage or a surety bond as required in section 14-49.

div.head: Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34; fire prevention and protection, ch. 38; floods, ch. 42; health and sanitation, ch. 46; historic preservation, ch. 50; planning, ch. 62; signs, ch. 66; solid waste, ch. 70; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; road naming and addressing, § 74-31 et seq.; subdivisions, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 94; zoning, app. A. State Law reference— Water Well Standards Act of 1985, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-120; ordinances relating to repair, closing and demolition of dwellings unfit for human habitation or buildings or structures that imperil health, safety or morals, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11; authority to demolish structures where drug crimes are committed, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; authority to repair, close or demolish unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; county or municipal ordinances relating to unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 18-1. - Contractor's debris, waste; removal. (a) All persons, partnerships, corporations, contractors or associations engaged in the business of building, clearing of land, clearing of trees, roots and stumps, removal of refuse and debris from premises on which the refuse was or is located shall dispose of such debris, refuse, stumps, trees or other wastes by hauling it to a public or private dump. Except as otherwise provided in this section, no such wastes shall be piled or placed upon adjoining premises or upon any property not a public or private waste dump within the city. Refuse, waste and debris may be piled or placed on property: (1) Where such waste, refuse or debris is used for a fill, provided that when so used the waste shall be covered with dirt. (2) Where application is made to the city manager for exceptions to this section, and with good cause being shown, the city manager makes a specific exception, each specific exception to be reported to the city council and recorded in the minute book of the city. (b) The intent of this section is to avoid unsightly piling of debris, refuse and waste on premises adjoining developed property, and to eliminate breeding places for snakes and other animals which may be dangerous to the safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the city. (Code 1986, § 8-2-4) Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 70. Secs. 18-2—18-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION CODES[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Access to and use of public facilities by physically handicapped persons, O.C.G.A. § 30-3-1 et seq.; construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; water efficiency requirements, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26; fire escapes in buildings, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50; authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(12).
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 18-31. - Self inspection exemption. Pursuant to the authority contained in section 3, 1996 Georgia Laws, page 1632, at page 1634, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26(d), relating to self-inspection of water and sewer projects by master plumbers or utility contractors, shall not be applicable within the city. (Ord. No. 96-14, § 1, 8-12-1996) Secs. 18-32—18-50. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ADOPTION
Sec. 18-51. - Adoption by reference. The following technical building and construction codes are adopted by reference and may be amended for later editions as required by the Georgia Uniform Codes Act, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25: (1) International Building Code (IBC), (2) National Electrical Code as published by the National Fire Protection Association, (3) International Fuel Gas Code (IFGC), (4) International Mechanical Code (IMC), (5) International Plumbing Code (IPC), (6) International Residential Code (IRC), (7) International Energy Conservation Code (IECC), (8) International Fire Code (IFC), (9) International Existing Building Code (IEBC), (10) International Swimming Pool and Spa Code (ISPSC), (11) International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC), (12) Title 8, Chapter 2, Article 3 (Application of Building and Fire Related Codes to Existing Buildings). (Code 1986, §§ 8-2-11, 8-2-21, 8-2-31, 8-2-41, 8-2-51, 8-2-61, 8-2-71; Ord. No. 2017-01, 2-13-2017) Secs. 18-52—18-70. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - AMENDMENTS
Sec. 18-71. - Building code. The building code is amended to permit the use of SDR-41 ASTM D 3033 sewer pipe or plastic pipe of equal quality. (Code 1986, § 8-2-12) Sec. 18-72. - Electrical code. The electrical code is amended by addition of the following language: (1) A duplex 110-volt outlet shall be included on an individual circuit in any garage or covered carport. (2) Reserved. (3) No employee of an electric power supplier shall install a meter in any new building in the city without a city electrical inspection seal on the meter base certifying that the final inspection has been made on the building. (4) All outside entrance cables, including those through all walls, shall be two-inch rigid conduit. (5) No aluminum wiring shall be used in any building within the city, except as provided in subsection (6) of this section. (6) The use of number 210 or larger aluminum entrance cable is permitted in the city. (Code 1986, § 8-2-22; Ord. No. 2013-03, § 1, 4-8-2013) Sec. 18-73. - Plumbing code. The plumbing code is amended by addition of the following language: (1) Tap-ons. a. All tap-ons to the city sewerage system must be made by a plumber licensed in the city. b. All tap-ons to the city water system must be made by the city. c. The responsibility of choosing a plumber will be left to the discretion of the builder, developer, contractor or individual wanting the tap-on. A list of licensed plumbers in the city will be available at city hall. d. The city will point out the sewer line location to the plumber. e. From this point on, it will be the plumber's responsibility to open the hole to make the tap-on. f. Except as provided in Fort Oglethorpe, Georgia, Code of Ordinances Part 2, Chapter 78, Subdivisions, Article IV, Section 78-97, the city shall be responsible for installing a water line to the city meter and 24 inches beyond the meter in order to protect the integrity of the city's water meter. The owner shall pay all cost and expenses incident to the connection of the building water line to city's line 24 inches beyond the meter. g. After opening and tap-on is made, it must be inspected by the city building inspector for proper installation. h. The street opening shall be filled with 33p gravel (crusher run) and tamped every six inches until the hole is filled. At this point the blacktop will be cut back four inches all around the hole to undisturbed roadbed, and four inches of new asphalt will be installed and packed with roller. i. Heavily traveled roads require four inches of concrete with three-quarter-inch reinforcing rods and two inches of blacktop rolled to be installed. This operation will be inspected by the city building inspector. j. All of the above must meet city and state specifications on the tap-on and street repair (with one-year warranty on street repair). k. Tap-on fee to be determined by EQR schedule plus permit, $16.00. l. The city council reserves the right to waive water and sewer tap fees on existing residents covered by Resolution No. 87-32. m. A copy of this subsection (1) will be included with each permit. (2) The use of PVC, schedule 40, rigid pipe is permitted in the city, above and below ground. (3) The use of SDR-41 ASTM D 3033 sewer pipe or plastic pipe of equal quality is permitted in the city. (Code 1986, § 8-2-32; Ord. No. 2013-19, § I-B, 9-9-2013) Editor's note— The resolution referenced in subsection (1)(l) of the preceding section is not set out at length in this Code but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. Sec. 18-74. - Housing code. Subsection (a)3. of section 103.2 of the Standard Housing Code is deleted in its entirety, and the following is substituted in lieu thereof: Allow 30 days' time for performance of any act it requires. (Code 1986, § 8-2-62) Secs. 18-75—18-105. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FLOW-RATE RESTRICTIONS ON PLUMBING FIXTURES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Flow-rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3.
Sec. 18-106. - Water conserving facilities required. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial means any type of building other than residential. Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet or urinal in an existing building. Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling, but shall not include a hotel or motel. (b) Prohibited construction. On or after July 1, 1991, no construction may be initiated within the city for any residential building of any type which: (1) Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve, or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.6 gallons of water per flush; however, this subsection shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992; (2) Employs a shower head that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; (3) Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of one gallon of water per flush; (4) Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than two gallons of water per minute; or (5) Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. (c) Commercial buildings. On or after July 1, 1992, there shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated within the city for any commercial building of any type which does not meet the requirements of subsections (b)(1) through (5). (d) Application to replacement of toilets, showers. The requirements of subsection (b) shall apply to any residential construction initiated after July 1, 1991, and to any commercial construction initiated after July 1, 1992, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers or both. (e) Exemptions. New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of subsections (b), (c) and (d) when: (1) The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewerage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; (2) Such plumbing or sewerage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this section were installed; (3) Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or (4) Units to be installed are: a. Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; b. Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or c. Toilets for juveniles. The owner, or his agent, of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsection (e)(2), (3) or (4) shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the building inspector for the city. A fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. (f) Enforcement; penalty. (1) This section shall be enforced by the office of the building inspector of the city. Citations for violations may be issued by the chief building inspector of the city. (2) Any person violating this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in Charter section 4.13. (Code 1986, § 8-2-33)
