The term "emergency condition," for purposes of this section, shall mean any condition or circumstance which the fire marshal or fire chief judges to constitute an immediate threat or danger to the occupants of the building, structure, facility or premises or to persons or property exposed to a fire, the hazards associated with fire, explosion, the threat of fire or explosion, or exposed to risks from some other hazardous condition or circumstance. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-38, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-89. - Implied consent. Any application for or the acceptance of any approval, permit, license or certificate requested, or required pursuant to this article or other applicable law or ordinance of this city or state, constitutes agreement and consent by the person making the application, or accepting the approval, permit, license or certificate to allow the fire marshal or his representatives to enter the building, structure, facility or premises at any reasonable time to conduct inspections as may be deemed appropriate by the fire marshal or as otherwise provided by this article or other applicable ordinances, rules, regulations or state law. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-39, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-90. - Notice of or order to eliminate dangerous or unlawful conditions. (a) Whenever the fire marshal or his designated representative finds any violation of this article or any fire hazard, he is authorized to issue or serve a written notice of the findings of an inspection as set forth in this chapter and to notify the building official. (b) Whenever the fire marshal or his designated representative finds any violation of this article or any fire hazard which is deemed to create a serious or significant potential threat to life in event of fire or explosion, he is authorized to issue a written order to correct or abate the violation or hazard. Such order when issued shall set forth a reasonable and realistic time frame or date limit for correction, abatement or compliance. The time frame for correction, abatement or compliance established by or as directed by the fire marshal, or his designated representative, may be reasonably correlated by him to the seriousness or relative degree of hazard, and/or to the complexity of the means of correction or abatement. (c) Where deemed necessary, due to the potential of risk of life or property, the fire marshal may issue a verbal order for the immediate correction or abatement of a violation or fire hazard. This may be followed by a written order or notice of action. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-40, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-91. - Summary abatement. The fire marshal or the fire chief shall have the authority to summarily abate any violation of this article or any fire hazard which constitutes an immediate or imminent danger or threat to life in their opinion, and where the following of the provisions for obtaining corrective action or abatement as set forth elsewhere in this article is not practical in their judgment. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-41, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-92. - Unsafe buildings or structures. An unsafe building or structure is any building or structure which is deemed to be structurally unsafe or which is not provided with adequate means of egress, or which is deemed to constitute a serious fire hazard, or which is otherwise deemed dangerous to human life, or which in relation to existing use constitutes a hazard to the safety, health or welfare of the public by reason of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, obsolescence, fire damage, disaster damage, vandalism, flood damage or abandonment, as specified in this article or by any other applicable codes or ordinances in force in the city. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-42, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-93. - Serving notices or orders. (a) The service of notices or orders issued in connection with this section may be made by the fire marshal or his representative upon the owner, occupant or person in charge of the building, structure, facility, premises or portion thereof where the hazard or violation was found, or by delivering a copy of the notice or order to any or all of the persons noted. If such person cannot be served by delivery as noted, service may be accomplished by affixing a copy of the notice or order in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance of the building, structure, facility or premises, or by delivering or sending a copy of the notice or order to the known agent of the owner or occupant, or in the event of an absentee owner with no known agent, by sending a copy by certified or registered mail to the owner's last known residence, business or post office address. (b) If the building, structure, facility or premises is owned by one or more persons and is occupied by one or more other persons under lease or otherwise, the notice or order issued in connection with this section shall apply to the addition to or changes in the building, structure or premises such as would immediately become real estate and become the property of the owner and not the occupant unless it is otherwise agreed between or among the owner and the occupant. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-43, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-94. - Failure to comply; violations and penalties; removal of prohibited conditions and violation. (a) Any person who shall fail to comply with an order of correction or abatement as set forth in this section, or who shall build or act in violation of this article or of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved under authority of this article in connection with any approval, certificate or permit issued under this article, or who shall perform any act deemed to create a serious potential for fire or explosion and for which the issuance of an order to correct or abate is not adequate, and who is found guilty shall be guilty of a violation of this article. A person found guilty under this section shall, for each and every violation and noncompliance respectively, be subject to punishment as provided in Charter section 4.13. The imposition of penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and the responsible person shall be required to correct or abate such violation within a time limit as ordered by the court. When not otherwise specified, each five days a prohibited condition or violation continues following an order of the court to correct or abate such violation within a time limit as ordered by the court to correct or abate the condition shall constitute a separate offense. (b) When the fire marshal, the fire chief or their authorized representative determine that violations of this article warrant the filing of charges or action of the court as provided for in subsection (a) of this section, the issuing of a citation of charges and/or summons to appear before the municipal court upon request of the fire marshal, the fire chief or their authorized representative, is authorized. (c) In addition to the filing of charges as specified in subsections (a) and (b) of this section or as a separate remedy at law, the fire marshal or fire chief may seek injunctive relief for any fire hazard, violation or condition that threatens the safety of life based on the provisions of this article or any applicable code or ordinance of the city or of the state. (d) The application of penalties by the court as provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions or violations. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-44, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-95. - Removal of notices or orders; illegal use of buildings. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to use a building, structure, facility or premises in violation of the provisions of this article where an order has been affixed to the building prohibiting the use of the building under authority of any provision of this article without the approval of the fire marshal or his authorized representative or the court. (b) When it is determined that the occupancy or use of a building has changed from that shown on the certificate of occupancy issued by the building official, the fire marshal may issue such notice or orders as necessary and in conformance with this article to remove or remedy any noted violations or hazards and he shall refer the building to the building official for any repairs, alterations, remodeling, removing or demolition required. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-45, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-96. - Coordination with and application of related codes; application of the adopted building code, life safety code and related codes. (a) The planning, design and construction of new buildings, structures, facilities or premises shall be in conformance with the building code, electrical code, gas code, mechanical code, zoning code and the life safety code, as adopted by the city council; however, where operations, contents, processes or conditions are not covered by such codes, the applicable provisions of this article shall apply. (b) Any alterations, additions or changes required in existing buildings, structures, facilities or premises because of a change in use, occupancy, exit design or other reason shall be made in compliance with the codes noted in subsection (a) of this section and as set forth in section 38-81. (c) The fire marshal and the building official shall coordinate their review of plans on new construction and/or renovations or alterations of existing buildings so as to ascertain compliance with the codes and standards under their respective jurisdictions. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-46, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-97. - Alternate materials and methods. (a) New construction. The fire marshal and the building official shall have the authority to jointly consider and approve a modification of any of the applicable codes for new construction with regard to matters relating to fire protection and safety to life in event of fire or related emergencies where the proposed design fire protection system, building use, or construction method involved is unusual or where such involves an unusual hazard, condition or hardship, and the provisions of the codes and standards of force do not clearly or adequately deal with the proposed design, protection system application or design, building use, or construction method, in their judgment. (b) Alternate materials. It is the intent of this section to allow the use of designs, systems, methods or devices of equivalent or superior quality, strength, fire resistance, effectiveness, durability and safety to those prescribed by the applicable codes and standards, provided technical documentation, data, or other information or material acceptable to the fire marshal and building official is submitted for review and such demonstrates to their satisfaction the equivalency of the design, system, method or device for the intended use. Any modification or alternate safeguard jointly approved by the fire marshal and building official shall not afford a condition less safe to life and, where appropriate, property, than in their judgment would be provided with compliance with the provisions of applicable codes. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-47, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-98. - Modifications and appeals. (a) Existing conditions. The fire marshal shall have the authority to grant a variance to the provisions of this article, or of the codes or standards adopted by reference by this article, upon application in writing by the owner and/or occupant of an existing building, structure, facility or premises, or by his authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of this article or the codes or standards adopted by reference by this article or the city. Such modification or variance may be granted by the fire marshal provided in his judgment the spirit, intent and purposes of this article are observed, the public safety shall be reasonably and practically secured, the modification is in the interest of the community, and substantial justice will be done. The particulars of any variance granted or allowed and the decision of the fire marshal shall be approved or disapproved by the city council at its next duly scheduled meeting. (b) Right to appeal. Whenever the fire marshal or fire chief shall issue an order pursuant to this article, disapprove an application, refuse to grant a permit, refuse to grant a waiver or modification, or when it is claimed that the provisions of this article or the codes and standards adopted by reference by this article or the city do not apply or that their true intent and meaning have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant or aggrieved party may appeal from the order or decision of the fire marshal or fire chief to the board of adjustments and appeals as established by the adopted building code of the city within 30 days after the decision is rendered by the fire marshal or fire chief. The provisions of the applicable building code relative to time limits, variations and modifications, and decisions as connected with the appeals to the board, shall be applicable to appeals from the fire marshal or the fire chief relating to this article. If not satisfied with the decision of the board, appeal may be made to the court of appropriate jurisdiction. Every decision of the board relative to this article shall be filed in the office of the fire marshal. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-48, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-99. - General provisions. (a) Interference with fire officials. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, abuse or obstruct in any way the fire chief, fire marshal or their representatives in carrying out any actions in accordance with their official duties as set forth by this article, or by any other applicable local ordinance, or by any law or regulation of the state. (b) Unlawful use of credentials; unlawful impersonation of fire official. It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to use an official or unofficial badge or credential so as to impersonate an authorized fire official or to otherwise impersonate a fire official. (c) Authority to investigate fires, explosions, false alarms or related incidents. The fire marshal or his authorized representatives are authorized to investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of any fire or explosion, or to investigate any incident resulting from the sending or sounding of a false alarm of fire or a bomb threat. When in the judgment of the fire marshal reasonable cause exists that a fire or explosion may have been of criminal origin, the fire marshal or his authorized representative is authorized to locate and take custody of any or all physical evidence relating to the cause of the fire or explosion and to continue the investigation to the extent deemed appropriate within the limits of fire prevention bureau resources and within the limits of applicable state laws. The fire marshal shall inform the police department of each fire of criminal or suspected criminal origin, false alarms or bomb threats. Also, he shall assist the police department in its investigations of reported incidents if so requested by that department. The police department shall be responsible for the investigation of fires and/or explosions of criminal or suspected criminal origin, false alarms or bomb threats so as to identify, apprehend and assist in the prosecution of the person responsible for such criminal act. (d) Evacuation of buildings, structures, facilities or premises. When, in the judgment of the fire marshal, the fire chief or their authorized representatives in their absence, there is an actual or serious potential danger to the occupants of or persons in close proximity of any building, structure, facility or premises because of unsafe structural conditions, the presence of explosives, explosive fumes or vapor, toxic fumes, gases or materials, the fire marshal, the fire chief, or their authorized representatives in their absence, may order the complete or partial immediate evacuation of any building, structure, facility or premises and, as necessary, areas in such proximity to these as to be endangered. All persons under order to evacuate shall promptly leave the evacuation area and shall not reenter until authorized to do so by the official who issued the evacuation order. This section shall not pertain to bomb threats where no bomb or explosive device is known to exist. In such bomb threat situations, the decision to evacuate or not to evacuate is the responsibility of the person in charge of the building, structure, facility or premises at that time. (e) Permits and approvals. No person shall maintain, store or handle materials, or conduct processes which produce conditions hazardous to life or property, or install equipment used in connection with such activities without first obtaining approval, or as appropriate based on the provisions of this article, a permit from the fire marshal. Where conditions or activities are also regulated by a state or federal agency and a permit, license or certificate is required by the regulating agency, no local permit is required; however, the approval of the fire marshal is required and he shall have the authority to apply the provisions of this article where a hazardous condition is discovered. (f) Tests. All equipment required by this article or other applicable codes adopted by the city or by the state shall be maintained in a safe, sound and operational condition. The fire marshal may require tests or test reports as proof of compliance. Required tests are to be made at the expense of the owner or his agent by an approved testing laboratory or other approval agency or firm acceptable to the fire marshal. (g) Authority to expose or stop work. Whenever any construction or installation coming under this article is subject to inspection prior to use and is covered or concealed without having first been inspected, the fire marshal may require by verbal and/or written order that such work be exposed for inspection. The fire marshal shall be notified when the installation is ready for inspection within a reasonable period of time. When any construction or installation work is being performed in violation of the plans, specifications or understandings as approved by the fire marshal, a written order may be issued to the responsible party to stop work on that portion of the work which is in violation. The order shall state the nature of the violation. No work shall be continued on that portion until the violation has been corrected. (h) Administrative liability. Any officer or employee of the city empowered or authorized to administer or act under the provisions of this article or other applicable codes in force in the city or adopted or required by the state, and acting for the city or state in the discharge of his duties, shall not be held liable personally; and he is relieved from all personal liability from any damages that may accrue to any person or property as a result of any act required, implied or permitted, in the discharge of his duties, or as required, implied or permitted by this article or other applicable codes in force in the city or adopted or required by the state. (i) Municipal liability. The city shall not be liable for any damage to persons or property resulting from any act or any failure to act in connection with any provision of this article or other applicable codes in force in the city or adopted or required by the state. (j) Permitting and inspection. The inspection or permitting of any building or plan by any employee of the division of fire prevention of the fire department under the requirements of this article shall not be construed in any court as a warranty of the physical condition of such building or the adequacy of such plan. Neither the city or any employee of the city shall be liable in tort for damages for any defect or hazardous or illegal condition or inadequacy in such building or plan, nor for any failure or any component of such building, which may occur subsequent to such inspection or permitting. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-49, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-100. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Approved means acceptable to the fire marshal, or as appropriate, the fire chief, of the city. In determining acceptability of installations, equipment, materials or procedures, the fire marshal, or as appropriate the fire chief, may base acceptance on compliance with nationally recognized standards. The fire marshal, or as appropriate the fire chief, may require evidence of proper installation, proper use or use of proper procedures. The fire marshal, or as appropriate the fire chief, may also refer to listings or labeling practices of recognized testing laboratories, inspection agencies or other recognized organizations concerned with product evaluations and which are in a position to determine compliance with appropriate standards for the current production of listed items and the satisfactory performance of such equipment or materials in actual usage. Building code means the building code adopted in section 18-51. Building official means the building official of the city. Chief of police means the Chief of the Fort Oglethorpe Police Department, Fort Oglethorpe, Georgia. Chief of the fire department or fire chief means the fire chief of the Fort Oglethorpe Fire Department, Fort Oglethorpe, Georgia. Combustible means capable of undergoing combustion. Electrical code means the electrical code adopted in section 18-51. Exit discharge means that portion of a means of egress between the termination of an exit and a public way. Fire hazard means: (1) Any thing or act which increases or may cause an increase of the hazard or menace of fire to a greater degree than that customarily recognized as normal by persons in the public service regularly engaged in preventing, suppressing or extinguishing fire; (2) Any thing or act which may obstruct, delay, hinder or interfere with the operations of the fire department or with the egress of occupants in event of fire; (3) A condition which will increase the spread or extent of fire; or (4) A definite condition of materials, rather than the materials themselves, which has the potential to produce a fire cause. Gas code means the gas code adopted in section 18-51. Mechanical code means the mechanical code adopted by section 18-51. Overcrowding means a condition: (1) When there are more people in the building or portion of the building than is allowed or posted in accordance with the building code, or where applicable, the state safety fire law; or (2) When in the judgment of the fire marshal or his representative a threat to the safety of life exists due to the number of persons sitting or standing so as to obstruct or impede the use of aisles, passages, corridors, exits or other components of required means of egress. Zoning code means the zoning code in appendix A of this Code. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-50, 4-24-1995) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 38-101. - Approvals and fire regulatory permits. (a) Permit required. No person shall maintain, store or handle materials or conduct processes which produce conditions hazardous to life or property, or install equipment used in connection with such activities without first obtaining approval, or as appropriate, a fire regulatory permit from the fire marshal as provided; however, the approval of the fire marshal is required, and he shall have the authority to apply the provisions of this article where a hazardous condition is discovered. (b) New activities. Any person desiring to conduct or engage in any new process or activity requiring a fire regulatory permit under this article shall apply for a permit as set forth in this section and shall be issued the permit prior to engaging in the conducting of the process or activity, or before occupying a building or structure requiring a permit. (c) Existing activities. Persons known to be conducting processes or activities required to be permitted under this article on or before the date of adoption of this article, shall be advised that a permit is required. Such persons may also be advised of any violations noted under this article that must be corrected before a permit can be issued. The fire marshal shall exercise reasonableness and shall apply the applicable provisions of sections 38-81 and 38-98 when applying the provisions of this article or of any of the technical standards adopted by reference under this article or otherwise adopted by the city council, when such are being applied to existing conditions or activities. No existing process or activity requiring a permit under this article and found to be in significant noncompliance with the applicable provisions of this article shall continue after a period of one year from the date the person is notified of the permit requirement. Where there is noncompliance, the fire marshal may issue a temporary permit with an established expiration date. A temporary permit issued in connection with this subsection may be extended provided a plan of corrective action has been submitted prior to the expiration of the permit, evidence clearly indicates that compliance is being obtained, and there are practical difficulties in completing the corrective action by the expiration date. (d) Permitted action. A fire regulatory permit shall constitute permission to maintain, store or handle materials, or to conduct processes which may produce conditions hazardous to life or property, or to install equipment used in connection with such activities. A permit shall not be a substitute for any license or certificate required by law. A permit issued shall be construed to be a license to proceed with work and shall not be construed as authority to violate, cancel, alter or set aside any of the provisions of this article. The issuance of a permit shall not be construed as preventing the fire marshal from thereafter requiring correction of errors in plans or in construction, or of violations of this article. (e) Transfer of permit prohibited. A fire regulatory permit shall not be transferable, and any change in use or occupancy of a building or premises shall require a new permit. A fire regulatory permit shall continue until revoked or for such a period of time as designated at the time of issuance. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-51, 4-24-1995) Sec. 38-102. - Applying for a fire regulatory permit; related provisions. (a) Application for permit. An application for a permit shall be made to the fire marshal on a form available at the division of fire prevention. The form shall be fully completed. The application shall be accompanied by such data as may be required by the fire marshal and by the required fee, as set forth in subsection (c) of this section. (b) Agreement to comply; responsibility. The filing of an application for a permit or a request for an approval from the fire marshal under this article constitutes an agreement on the part of the person the applicant represents to comply with the provisions of this article and of the technical codes and standards adopted by reference under this article or otherwise adopted by the city council. Such filing shall also constitute an understanding on the part of the permittee that the permittee, not the city, the fire marshal or the fire chief, shall bear the full responsibility for any damages to persons and/or property in connection with any fire, explosion or other accident or event involving any process, material, installation or activity covered by a permit or approval issued in connection with any of the provisions of this article. (c) Processing fee. There shall be a processing fee as stated in the schedule of fees and charges for the issuance of a fire regulatory permit. The fee shall accompany the permit application when it is filed. If an inspection conducted to determine compliance with this article reveals that a condition exists which would preclude the issuance of a permit, the processing fee shall not be refunded. Further, where a permit is denied due to violations and hazards noted, the activity for which the permit is required shall not be deemed in compliance. The fire marshal may require the filing of a new application and fee if he deems the original application and fee to have been filed prematurely or filed with false or incomplete information. Such fee shall not be required of government, charitable or religious organizations. (d) Review of applications; issuance. The fire marshal or his authorized representative shall review applications submitted and issue approvals or permits as required provided the data on the application and plans and specifications submitted with the application indicate to a reasonable degree compliance with the provisions of this article and the technical codes and standards adopted by reference under this article or otherwise adopted by the city council. Permits for activities requiring evidence of financial responsibility on the part of the permittee as required by this article shall not be issued unless proof of required financial responsibility is furnished. (e) Rejected. If an application for a permit or approval is rejected by the fire marshal or his authorized representative, the applicant shall be advised of the reasons for such rejection. (f) Display of permits. A copy of the fire regulatory permit shall be posted or shall otherwise be readily accessible at each place a permitted activity is performed. As required by the fire marshal, a permit holder may be required to carry the permit. (g) Records. A record of fire regulatory permits issued and any exceptions granted shall be maintained in the fire prevention bureau. Such record shall be available for public inspection during normal business hours upon request to the fire marshal. (h) Duration of permits; limitations on issuance. A fire regulatory permit issued under this article shall continue until revoked or for the period of time designated in the permit at the time of issuance of the permit. The permit shall be issued to one person only and for the location or purpose described in the permit. Any change which affects any of the conditions of the permit shall require a new permit. The fire marshal may grant an extension of the permit period where an expiration date has been established upon presentation by the permittee of a satisfactory reason for failure to start or complete the work or activity authorized by the permit by the designated expiration date. A permit issued shall become invalid unless the use authorized by such is commenced within six months after issuance, or if the use authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of six months after the time the use of the permit is commenced. One or more extensions of time, for periods not to exceed 90 days each, may be allowed for the permit provided the extension is requested in writing and justifiable cause is demonstrated. Extensions granted by the fire marshal shall be in writing. (i) Temporary permit. When a potentially hazardous situation or activity of a temporary nature is encountered, and is not specifically regulated by this article, a permit may be required by and issued by the fire marshal to cover the duration of the situation or activity. He shall require the filing of an application and fee as set forth for a regular fire regulatory permit. (j) Consolidated permit. Only one permit shall be required for each location of a firm which may be required to obtain more than one permit under the permit requirements of this article. Such consolidated permit shall list all of the materials or activities covered by the permit. Revocation of any of the permitted materials or activities covered by the consolidated permit shall require the revocation of the permit and issuance of a new permit. In such situation, a new and revised permit may be issued by the fire marshal for the materials or activities not covered by the revocation. No new application is required and no fee is required for the revised consolidated permit. (k) Revocation of permits. The fire marshal may revoke his approval of a permit issued under the provisions of this article when it is determined there has been any false statements or misrepresentation as to the material facts in the application or in the plans on which the approval or permit was based. Further, the fire marshal may revoke his approval or a permit upon determination by him that the occupancy, operation or activity for which the approval or permit or was issued is in violation of or is not in conformity with the provisions of this article or with other applicable codes adopted by the city or with applicable laws, rules or regulations of the state jurisdiction; and the fire marshal may notify the responsible agency of any noted violation, nonconformance or condition deemed to be hazardous. (Ord. No. 95-2, § 4-2-52, 4-24-1995) ARTICLE IV. - OPEN BURNING
Sec. 38-121. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: (a) A fire permit is issued by the fire department of the City of Fort Oglethorpe allowing for the outdoor burning of a limited nature during the burning period. Permits may be applied for Monday through Friday on the day of the proposed burning activity. A permit for burning activity on Saturday must be sought on the immediately preceding Friday. (b) A fire control device is an operable fire extinguisher or operating water hose attached to a functioning and open water hydrant. (c) A blue permit when issued by the fire office of the City of Fort Oglethorpe allows for the reduction of leaves on the premises on which they fall by the person in control of the premises, or for disposal of tree limbs from storm damage as outlined in the Rules for Air Quality Control, chapter 391-3-1 (5)(a), (1) and (7). (d) A white permit is required for burning on construction sites, in heavily populated areas, or other areas not outlined in the blue print. A white permit shall be issued without an inspection of the proposed burning area and material first being conducted by an authorized agent of the fire department of the City of Fort Oglethorpe, and payment of the inspection and issuance fee determined by the fire department of the City of Fort Oglethorpe. (e) Material or burning is any matter of a flammable nature or which is capable of being or becoming combustible. (f) Structure or dwelling is any man made building, whether for commercial, public or personal use, or other improvement upon real property. (g) Owner or occupant is the record owner or the person occupying the premises upon which burning is to take place under a lease or rental or other agreement for occupation. In the case of a corporation or other legal entity, "owner" or "occupant" shall include an authorized agent of the corporation or legal entity. (h) Burning period is the hours between 9:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. of the same day consisting of a total of 7½ hours per day and consisting of the same hourly framework whether eastern daylight time or eastern standard time is in effect; however, no burning period exists on Sunday. (i) Waste disposal service is the city garbage collection and disposal service or any public or private entity performing garbage collection and disposal within the incorporated limits of the City of Fort Oglethorpe. (j) Burning activity is any activity or action resulting in the combustion or burning of any material within the incorporated limits of the City of Fort Oglethorpe. (k) Exceptional circumstances are those state of facts wherein the need to burn material on a construction site, requires or creates a specific and articulable hardship on the applicant for a white permit as determined by the fire office of the City of Fort Oglethorpe. (l) Rules for Air Quality Control refers to chapter 391-3-01-02(5)(a), (b) revised September, 1995. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-4-1, 1-26-1998; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 2, 12-11-2000; Ord. No. 2003-1, § 1, 3-24-2003) Sec. 38-122. - Burning prohibited—Time, place and manner of prohibition; exceptions. (a) Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section, all burning within the incorporated limits of the City of Fort Oglethorpe is prohibited. (b) Burning will be allowed, within the incorporated limits of the City of Fort Oglethorpe, if: (1) The material to be burned cannot be removed by the waste disposal service employed within the incorporated limits of the City of Fort Oglethorpe; (2) There is no other reasonable method to dispose of the material; (3) The material is at least 50 feet from any structure; unless greater distance is imposed later in this code; (4) An owner or occupant of the premises upon which the material is to be burned is present with a functioning fire control device for the duration of the burning activity; (5) The material to be burned does not in any way consist of paper, cardboard, paperboard, treated wood, foam, lead paint, asbestos, rubber, plastics, tires, roofing materials (including shingles) sheetrock or gypsum board (or similar building materials), tar paper, petroleum products, or other material of a polluting nature; and (6) All burning must conform to "Rules for Air Quality Control"; reference O.C.G.A., § 391-3-1-02(5)(a), (b) revised September, 1995, as follows. (a) No person shall cause, suffer allow, or permit open burning in any area of the State except as follows: 1. Reduction of leavers on the premises on which they fall by the person in control of the premises, unless prohibited by local ordinance and/or regulation; 2. Carrying out recognized agricultural procedures necessary for production or harvesting of crops; 3. Destruction of combustible demolition or construction materials either on site or transported to a burning facility upon approval by the director, unless prohibited by local ordinance and/or regulation; 4. The burning over of any forest land by the owners of such land; 5. For recreational purposes or cooking food for immediate human consumption; 6. Fires set for purposes of training fire-fighting personnel when authorized by the appropriate governmental entity and the guidelines set forth by the director are strictly observed; 7. Disposal of tree limbs from storm damage; 8. For weed abatement, disease, and pest prevention; 9. Operation of devices using open flames such as tar kettle, blow torches, welding torches, portable heaters and other flame-making equipment; 10. Setting and maintenance by contractors and tradesmen of miscellaneous small fires necessary to such activities as streetpaving work installation or repair of utilities, provided that such fires are kept small in size, no smoke emissions exceeded 40 percent opacity, and that local ordinances and regulations do not prohibit such actions; 11. Open burning in other than predominantly residential areas for the purpose of land clearing or construction or right-of-way maintenance proved the following condition are met: (i) Prevailing winds at the time of the burning are away from the major portion of the area's population; (ii) The location of the burning is at least 1,000 feet from any dwelling located in a predominately residential area; (iii) The amount of dirt on or in the material being burned is minimized; (iv) Heavy oils, asphaltic materials, items containing natural or synthetic rubber, or any material other than plant growth are not being burned; (v) No more than one pile 60 feet by 60 feet, or equivalent, is being burned within a nine acre area at one time. 12. Disposal of all packaging materials previously containing explosives, in accordance with U.S. Department of Labor Safety Regulations; 13. Open burning of vegetative material for the purpose of land clearing using an air curtain destructor provided the following conditions are met: (b) Specific county restrictions. 1. In those counties whose total population, as listed census, exceeds 65,000, the legal exception subparagraphs 1., 2., 4., 5., 6., 10., 12., and 13, under subsection (a) above. Provided, however, that such burning, whenever feasible, be conducted between 10:00 a.m. and one hour before sunset and does not cause air pollution in quantities or characteristics or of a duration which is injurious or which unreasonably interferes with the enjoyment of life or use of property in such area of the state as is affected thereby. If it can be demonstrated that adequate disposal facilities for the particular combustible materials involved are not reasonable available, the other items under subsection (a) may also be allowed upon approval by the divisions. 2. Beginning in calendar year 1996 in those counties of Cherokce, Clayton, Cobb, Coweta, DeKalb, Douglas, Fayette, Forsyth, Fulton, Gwinnerr, Henry, Paling and Rochdale, the only legal exceptions to the general prohibition against open burning during the months of May, June, July, August and September shall be exception subparagraphs 2., 5., 6., 9, 10, and 12, under subsection (a) above provided however, that such burning, whenever feasible, be conducted between 10:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. The provisions of this paragraph 2. Shall not be effective until the following actions are taken: (i) The division shall investigate and prepare recommendations on the air quality and solid waste impacts of the general prohibition on the activities listed in subparagraphs 1., 3., 4., 7., 8., 11., and 13. of subsection (a). (ii) The division shall prepare the recommendations specified in 2. (i) with the cooperation and input form persons and organizations affect by this paragraph (ii), and with the U.S. EPA. The recommendations shall be prepared by September 1, 1994. (iii) Based on the recommendations and U.S. EPA's approval, this subsection (6) may be modified to reflect economics of disposal and overall environment benefits. (7) The size of the pile shall be limited to four feet by four feet or equivalent for all other piles not listed above. (8) Burning must take place within the burning period, unless exceptional circumstances exist wherein written permission is granted by the office of the fire marshal of the City of Fort Oglethorpe for burning to take place outside of the burning period; (9) Environmental conditions are suitable for burning as determined by the fire office of the City of Fort Oglethorpe and Georgia Forestry Commission requirements and the Environmental Protection Agency and Air Pollution Control Bureau regulations. (10) Either a white permit or a blue permit is issued by the first office of the City of Fort Oglethorpe. (c) Permits shall contain the following information: 1. A blue permit shall meet the following prescribed form and be available at the fire office of the City of Fort Oglethorpe: BLUE PERMIT (OPEN BURNING PERMIT) The applicant hereby agrees to only burn fallen leaves, or fallen tree limbs subject to the following conditions: 1. Burning is allowed on approved days only. 2. Burning is allowed only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. 3. The following materials ill not be burned; paper, cardboard, paperboard, treated wood, form, lead paint, asbestos materials, rubber, garbage, plastics, tires, stumps, roofing materials (including shingles), sheetrock or gypsum board (or other similar building material), tar paper, petroleum products, or any other polluting matter. 4. No salvage operation will be conducted by open burning i.e. boasts, insulated wire, automobiles. 5. The owner or the occupant of the premises must be present at all times with an operable fire extinguisher or garden hose connected to a functioning water hydrant. 6. This permit must be kept at or near the burning site and readily available for inspection. 7. Burning is allowed only at the mailing address of the applicant, listed below, unless otherwise noted. 8. This permit issued solely for your convenience. 9. This permit is not valid unless signed by the applicant and contains the applicant's address and phone number. 10. This permit is valid only for the days of issue. 11. An owner or occupant of the premises upon which this permit is used shall call the fire department office each day prior to burning to ensure burning is allowed for that day. This permit is effective for the (numeric date) day of (month) (year) ___________ APPLICANT ADDRESS: ___________ ___________ TELEPHONE NUMBER: ___________ WARNING: Noncompliance with any of the above conditions is a violation of the law, and is punished by fine or penalty. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-4-2, 1-26-1998; Ord. No. 2000-53, § 2, 12-11-2000; Ord. No. 2003-1, § 1, 3-24-2003) Sec. 38-123. - Burning complaints. (a) The city fire department and personnel assigned shall have the authority to extinguish any burning which is in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, and/or which constitutes an immediate threat to life or property. (b) Any complaint will result in the dispatch of a fire department unit to investigate. After such investigation the officer in charge shall determine if any provision of this chapter has been violated or constitutes a nuisance. (c) After an investigation of a burning complaint, if the officer in charge determines that a violation exists, the officer may elect to issue a citation for the violation. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-4-3, 1-26-1998) Sec. 38-124. - Penalties. Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter, hereby adopted, or fails to comply therewith, shall for each and every violation and non-compliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor as defined by the state. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation to continue. Penalties cannot exceed $1,000.00 or imprisonment of more than one year, or both, with the amount of fine/imprisonment being within the discretion of the municipal court of the city based upon the severity or repetition of the infraction. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-4-4, 1-26-1998) Sec. 38-125. - Jurisdiction of violation of this chapter. As provided for by law, the municipal court of the city shall have the venue and jurisdiction of any citations issued under this chapter. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-4-5, 1-26-1998) Secs. 38-126—38-140. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS
Sec. 38-141. - Purpose. To insure as far as possible, the safety of the citizens and personnel of the city from the possible harmful effects of hazardous materials, the following article is adopted as an amendment to the fire prevention and protection ordinance to insure that the quantities and types of hazardous chemicals and extremely hazardous substances will be known and regulated within the city to insure as far as possible the safety of the citizens of the city from the dangers of hazardous materials. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-5-1, 1-26-1998) Sec. 38-142. - Scope. The following article is applicable to any facility that is required to prepare or have available material safety-data sheet(s) (MSDS) for hazardous chemicals under the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 and all regulations promulgated under that act, and any facility required to submit reports for extremely hazardous substances, as defined in 40 C.F.R. 355, Appendix A, and any facility owning, handling, transporting, storing or in any other manner or method dealing in class A, B and C explosives and blasting agents within the city. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-5-2, 1-26-1998) Sec. 38-143. - Reporting requirements. (a) The owner or operator of a facility subject to this article shall submit a material safety data sheet and any other required forms to the fire safety division, of the fire department. (b) Forms must be submitted on all hazardous chemicals present at the facility at any one time in amounts equal to or greater than 9,000 pounds (or 3,540 kilograms) and for all extremely hazardous substances present at the facility in an amount greater than or equal to 500 pounds (or 227 kilograms which is approximately 55 gallons) or the threshold planning quantity (TPQ), whichever is lower as defined in Title 40, Part 355, Appendix A of the Code of federal regulations, which provision is incorporated herein. (1) The owner or operator of a facility that is subject to this part shall submit the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Tier 24 to the fire and safety division, of the fire department, on an annual basis beginning on September 1, 1998. (2) The owner and operator will also be required to submit a material safety data sheet on all hazardous chemicals as designated by Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations section 1910.120, which provisions are incorporated herein. (3) The term hazardous chemical does not apply to the following: a. Any food, food additive, color additive, or cosmetic regulated by the Food and Drug Administration. b. Any substance present as a solid in any manufactured item to the extent exposure to the substance does not occur under normal conditions of use. c. Any substance to the extent it is used for personal, family, or household purposes, or is present in the same form and concentration as a private package for distribution and used by the general public. d. Any substance to the extent it is used in a research laboratory or a hospital, or other medical facility under the direct supervision of a technically qualified individual. (c) The facility will be subject to unannounced inspections by the fire safety division of the fire department to insure compliance with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-5-3, 1-26-1998) Sec. 38-144. - Labeling requirements. (a) All locations within the city limits that contain hazardous materials must label all containers in conformity with current DOT guidelines. (b) The NFPA 704 system will also be required to be placed on a readily visible location of facilities to indicate hazardous materials. The above mentioned plaque must be securely mounted to the side of any truck, wall, construction trailer, etc. and be in a place at the location that is readily visible at all times; and be a minimum of at least 48 inches above ground level. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-5-4, 1-26-1998) Sec. 38-145. - Penalties. (a) MSDS reporting: Any person other than a government entity who violates any requirement of the article shall be in violation of this chapter. (b) Inventory reporting: Any person other than a governmental entity who violates any requirement shall be in violation of this chapter. (c) Continuing violations: Each day a violation described in paragraph (a) or (b) of this section continues shall constitute a separate violation. (d) Failure to permit: Any person that fails to obtain or maintain a required hazardous materials permit shall be in violation of this chapter. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-5-5, 1-26-1998) Sec. 38-146. - Explosives. (a) All class A, B and C explosives and blasting agents must be reported to the fire safety division. A permit will also be required for all explosives either stored or used within the city. A fee of $200.00 will be required of the entity involved with the above classes of explosives. The fee must be paid prior to issuance of the permit. (b) All units that store or contain explosives either mobile or fixed must have the proper DOT or NFPA plaques affixed to all four sides of the building or vehicle containing explosives. (c) Penalties. (1) Failure to report regulated explosives is a violation of this chapter. (2) Failure to obtain an explosive permit is a violation of this chapter. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-5-6, 1-26-1998) Sec. 38-147. - Penalties. Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter, hereby adopted, or fails to comply therewith, shall for each and every violation and non-compliance respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor as defined by the state. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation to continue. Penalties cannot exceed $1,000.00 or imprisonment of more than one year, or both, with the amount of fine/imprisonment being within the discretion of the municipal court of the city based upon the severity or repetition of the infraction. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-5-8, 1-26-1998) Sec. 38-148. - Jurisdiction of violation of this chapter. As provided for by law, the municipal court of the city shall have the venue and jurisdiction of any citations issued under this chapter. (Ord. No. 97-81, § 4-5-9, 1-26-1998) Sec. 38-149. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - FIRE LANE PROVISIONS
Sec. 38-150. - Purpose and scope. It is the declared purpose of this chapter to provide for the designation and identification of fire lanes, for the manner, method and language for the posting of signs; to establish the penalty for violation of this chapter, to identify and designate the persons who have authority to enforce the chapter and the limits of such authority, to prohibit parking in the fire lanes; to provide for the method of submitting properties to this chapter, to repeal all ordinances in conflict herein; and for other purposes. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-151. - Definitions. Enforcement officers shall refer to any duly authorized law enforcement officer employed by the city. Fine lanes are areas designated by the fire official providing access for fire department vehicles to buildings, fire department connections and fire hydrants. This includes all alleys, driveways or lanes, devoted to public use, where the parking of motor vehicles or other obstructions can interfere with ingress or egress of fire department vehicles for the protection of person and properties including, but not limited to, shopping centers, theaters, hospitals, bowling lanes, churches, multi-family housing, and high-rise buildings. Fire official means the fire officer or other designated authority, or their duly authorized representative, charged with the administration and enforcement of the fire prevention and protection ordinance. Master plans means all original plans drawn in accordance with this chapter; all copies distributed shall be from this original drawing. Need fire flow as defined by insurance services office fire suppression rating schedule. New building for the purpose of this chapter shall mean any commercial or public facility whose plans were submitted after this amendment goes into effect. Plats shall refer to maps created by the building owner and approved by the fire marshal or his designee which depict the location and boundaries of land and all existing fire lanes in accordance with this chapter. Such maps shall be drawn to scale. Property owners shall refer to each person, firm, corporation, or entity possessing any estate, or leasehold right in the property being designated as fire lanes. Ticket shall mean an order issued out of court by an enforcement officer of the city directing a violator of this chapter to comply with all civil fine set forth. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-152. - Identification. (a) Every existing building shall be accessible to fire department apparatus by way of access roadways with all-weather driving surfaces of not less than 20 feet (6.1 m) of unobstructed clear width, with adequate roadway turning radius capable to supporting the imposed loads of the fire apparatus and having a minimum vertical clearance of 13 feet 6 inches (4.1 m). (1) Where fire protection systems approved by the fire official are provided, the above required clearances may be modified by the fire official. (2) The fire official shall have the authority to require an increase in the minimum access widths where they are inadequate for fire or rescue operations. (b) Every new building shall be accessible to fire department apparatus by way of designated fire lanes with an all weather surface of not less than 20 feet (6.1 m) of unobstructed clear width. There shall be a minimum roadway turning radius of 35 feet (10.6 m). Three shall be a minimum vertical clearance of 13 feet 6 inches (4.1 m). The designated fire lanes shall be paved, purred concrete, or equivalent, capable of supporting the gross vehicle weight of fire apparatus. (1) Where fire protection systems approved by the fire official are provided, the above required clearances may be modified by the fire official. (2) The fire official shall have the authority to require an increase in the minimum access widths where they are inadequate for fire or rescue operations. (c) During construction, when combustibles are brought onto the site in such quantities as deemed hazardous by the fire official, access roads and a suitable water supply, acceptable to meet the required needed fire flow, shall be provided and maintained. (d) The areas designated as fire lanes hall have signs posted meeting the following criteria: (1) Signs shall read "No Parking Fire Lane", be constructed of a material to withstand the elements, such as metal, and lettering shall contrast against the background. (2) Letters shall not be less than two inches in height. (3) One sign shall be placed at the beginning of the fire lane and one at the end of the fire lane; each sign shall be erected not more than 50 feet apart. (4) Signs posted shall not be more than 4 feet from the edge of the curb and shall be visible from both driving directions, regardless of time of day, of the driving surfaces. (e) Painted lines, or equivalent, may be required by the fire official for that portion of the fire lane that is located in the parking areas, or is subject to blocking by parked vehicles. Such lines shall be yellow and clearly define an area 20 feet clear width from the building as no parking fire lane. (f) The fire official may require curbs of nonparking areas be painted red or other distinctive colors. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-153. - Approval; subsequent maintenance. All fire lanes shall be approved by the fire official pursuant to these regulations, and thereafter these fire lanes shall be maintained by the property owner. Designated fire lanes or roads deemed necessary for fire department access by the fire official shall be maintained in a passable condition. (a) Private property owners or their representatives shall be responsible for keeping all fire lanes within the city's jurisdiction free of all obstructions. (b) Public property owners, the City of Fort Oglethorpe or their representatives shall be responsible for keeping all fire lanes within the city's jurisdiction free of obstructions. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-154. - Erection of signs. No person or property owner shall place, erect or maintain any sign for control of parking or traffic which includes the words "Fire Lane" unless such location has been designated a fire lane by the fire official. Any failure to meet the applicable requirements specified in the City of Fort Oglethorpe Code shall be subject to a fine of $150.00 for each violation; provided, however, that the fine will be waived if the required specifications are made within 14 days he shall, on the 15 th day after receiving the citation, be subject to the $150.00 fine for each violation and an additional $10.00 fine for each violation for each day that the owner fails to comply with the provisions of this section until the area is properly designated and constructed. Each additional day shall be construed as an additional violation. All fines assessed under this section shall be paid into the treasury of the city. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-155. - Violations. No person shall park any motor vehicle, including a motorcycle, in a fire lane; provided, however, this section shall not apply to the parking of an authorized emergency vehicle on official business. (a) Enforcement of this section shall be through a civil action municipal court by the issuance of a ticket which shall be either left with the vehicle or delivered to the person in possession thereof. For purposes of such civil action, it shall be presumed that the registered owner of said vehicle is in control or possession thereof. (1) The first violation of parking in a fire lane within any 30 day period shall be punished by a $50.00 civil fine; provided, however the second violation within any 30 day period shall be punishable by a civil fine of $80.00; and a civil fine of $100.00 may be levied for each violation thereafter occurring within any 30 day period. (2) The person receiving a ticket for violation of this section may pay the civil fine(s) by return mail to the municipal court of the city or his designated receive within 48 hours of the issuance of the ticket or may request a hearing within 48 hours to contest the issuance of the ticket. In the event the civil fine is not paid within 48 hours, the municipal court may issue a warrant for failure to appear requiring the offender to show cause why he failed to pay the fine within 48 hours, the municipal court may issue a citation for contempt requiring the offender to show cause why he failed to pay the fine within the time frame allowed by this section. Upon conviction thereof, the municipal court may impose a fine as provided by law. (b) Upon any person to whom a ticket has been issued under this section, a uniform traffic citation may be obtained with a hearing date thereon from the police officer or uniformed fire inspector whereupon it shall be returnable to the municipal court. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-156. - Enforcement authority. A duly authorized law enforcement officer employed by the city and uniformed fire inspectors shall have the authority for enforcement of fire lanes. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-157. - Emergency authority. In addition to all powers authorize by state law, as amended, in the event of any fire, explosion, bomb threat, or similar emergency, the fire department in the city shall be authorized to prevent the blocking of any public or private street, road or alley, way or driveway, or emergency lane, during any such emergency or remove any vehicles or obstructions necessary. The officers, members, agent or employees of the fire department of the city shall not be liable at law for any act or acts done while actually fighting a fire or performing duties as the scene of an emergency. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-158. - Immunity from liability from enforcement of chapter pertaining to maintenance and clearing. The City of Fort Oglethorpe assumes no liability for any damages, injuries, or deaths resulting from enforcement or lack of enforcement, of the laws pertaining to maintenance and clearing of the fire lanes. The city has the authority to issue individual tickets or citations for fire lane violations, but the property owner has the ultimate responsibility to clear the fire lanes. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-159. - Enforceability of properly placed signs. The disregard or disobedience of the instruction of any sign placed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter by the driver of a vehicle shall be deemed prima facie evidence of a violation of law, without requiring proof by whom and by what authority such sign has been erected. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-160. - Petition requesting application of chapter to properties. Properties may become subject to this chapter by submitting a petition from the property owner of fully authorized agent of the property owner requesting this chapter to apply. The petition shall be submitted to the fire official and, upon approval, the property shall become subject to this chapter and its subsequent revisions. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001) Sec. 38-161. - Descriptions for fire officials. Property which falls within the jurisdiction of the City of Fort Oglethorpe shall have all fire delineations visually depicted on a plat. These plats shall be designed by the owner and submitted to the City of Fort Oglethorpe Fire Department and copies shall be maintained. Each visual depiction shall identify all building exterior walls, traffic and parking lanes, and sidewalks. The area(s) to be designed as fire lane(s) shall be delineated in red ink. The plat shall state a scale of th measurement and shall be on paper or a series of pages of not less than eight and one-half inches by 11 inches. The plat identification shall specify the name of the property, a brief legal description of the property, and the length and width of the fire lane(s), as approved by the fire official, with whom all master plats will be filed. (Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 8-27-2001)

div.head: Chapter 42 - FLOODS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2008-02, art. 1, §§ A—D, art. 2, §§ A—H, art. 3, §§ A—C, art. 4, §§ A—F, art. 5, and art. 6, adopted Feb. 25, 2008, repealed the former ch. 42, §§ 42-1—42-10, §§ 422-41—42-44, and §§42- 76—42-80, and enacted a new ch. 42 as set out herein. The former ch. 42 pertained to floods and derived from the Code of 1986, §§ 8-4-1—8-4-10, 8-4-21—8-4-24, 8-4-31, 8-4-32, 8-4-34—8-4-36. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 34; soil erosion and sedimentation control, § 34-31 et seq.; health and sanitation, ch. 46; planning, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; subdivisions, ch. 78; storm sewers and drainage in subdivisions, § 78-100; utilities, ch. 94; zoning, app. A; flood hazard overlay district (FH), app. A, art. XXI. State Law reference— Georgia Safe Dams Act of 1978, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-370 et seq.; construction and operation of watershed and flood control projects by counties, O.C.G.A. § 22-3-100 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 42-1. - Authorization. Article IX, section II of the state constitution and O.C.G.A., section 36-1-20(a) have delegated the responsibility to local governmental units to adopt regulations designed to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare of its citizenry. Therefore, the city does ordain as follows. (Ord. No. 2008-02, art. 1, § A, 2-25-2008) Sec. 42-2. - Findings of fact. (a) The flood hazard areas of the city are subject to periodic inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood and relief and protection, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. (b) These flood losses are caused by the occupancy in flood hazard areas of uses vulnerable to floods, which are inadequately elevated, floodproofed, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages, and by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains causing increases in flood heights and velocities. (Ord. No. 2008-02, art. 1, § B, 2-25-2008) Sec. 42-3. - Statement of purpose. It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the public health, safety and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: (1) Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities, which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; (2) Restrict or prohibit uses which are dangerous to health, safety and property due to water or erosion hazards, or which increase flood heights, velocities, or erosion; (3) Control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage or erosion; (4) Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert flood waters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands; and (5) Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers, which are involved in the accommodation of floodwaters. (Ord. No. 2008-02, art. 1, § C, 2-25-2008) Sec. 42-4. - Objectives. The objectives of this chapter are: (1) To protect human life and health; (2) To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; (3) To help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of flood-prone areas in such a manner as to minimize flood blight areas; (4) To minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; (5) To minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; (6) To minimize prolonged business interruptions; and (7) To insure that potential homebuyers are notified that property is in a flood area. (Ord. No. 2008-02, art. 1, § D, 2-25-2008) Sec. 42-5. - Definitions. Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in this chapter shall be interpreted so as to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this chapter its most reasonable application. Accessory structure means a structure having minimal value and used for parking, storage and other non-habitable uses, such as garages, carports, storage shed, pole barns, hay sheds and the like. Addition (to an existing building) means any walled and roofed expansion to the perimeter of a building which the addition is connected by a common load-bearing wall other that a firewall. Any walled and roofed addition, which is connected by a firewall or is separated by an independent perimeter load-bearing wall, shall be considered "new construction." Appeal means a request for a review of the city building official's interpretation of any provision of this chapter. Area of shallow flooding means a designated AO or AH zone on a community's flood insurance rate map (FIRM) with base flood depths from one to three feet, and/or where a clearly defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable and indeterminate, and where velocity flow may be evident. Area of special flood hazard is the land in the floodplain within a community subject to a one percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. In the absence of official designation by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, areas of special flood hazard shall be those designated by the local community and referenced in section 42-7. Base flood means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. Basement means that portion of a building having its floor subgrade (below ground level) on all sides. Building means any structure built for support, shelter, or enclosure for any occupancy or storage. Critical facility means any public or private facility, which, if flooded, would create an added dimension to the disaster or would increase the hazard to life and health. Critical facilities include: (1) Structures or facilities that produce, use, or store highly volatile, flammable, explosive, toxic, or water-reactive materials; (2) Hospitals and nursing homes, and housing for the elderly, which are likely to contain occupants who may not be sufficiently mobile to avoid the loss of life or injury during flood and storm events; (3) Emergency operation centers or data storage centers which contain records or services that may become lost or inoperative during flood and storm events; and (4) Generating plants, and other principal points of utility lines. Development means any man-made change to improved or unimproved real estate, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavating, drilling operations, and permanent storage or materials or equipment. Elevated building means a non-basement building built to have the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area elevated above the ground level by means of fill, solid foundation perimeter walls, pilings, columns, piers, or shear walls adequately anchored so as not to impair the structural integrity of the building during a base flood event. Existing construction is any structure for which the "start of construction" commenced before April 27, 1988 (i.e. the effective date of the first floodplain management code or ordinance adopted by the community as a basis for that community's participation in the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP)). Existing manufactured home park or subdivision means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including at a minimum the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed before April 27, 1988 (i.e. the effective date of the first floodplain management regulations adopted by a community). Expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision means the preparation of additional sites by the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed, including the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads. Flood or flooding means a general temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from: (1) The overflow of inland or tidal waters; or (2) The unusual and rapid accumulation runoff of surface waters from any source. Flood hazard boundary map (FHBM) means an official map of a community, issued by the federal insurance administration, where the boundaries of areas of special flood hazard have been defined as zone A. Flood insurance rate map (FIRM) means an official map of a community, issued by the federal insurance administration, delineating the areas of special flood hazard and/or risk premium zones applicable to the community. Flood insurance study the official report by the federal insurance administration evaluating flood hazards and containing flood profiles and water surface elevations of the base flood. Floodplain means any land area susceptible to flooding. Floodproofing means any combination of structural and non-structural additions, changes, or adjustments to structures, which reduce or eliminate flood damage to real estate or improved real property, water and sanitary facilities, structures and their contents. Floodway means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than a designated height. Freeboard means a factor of safety usually expressed in feet above a flood level for purposes of floodplain management. "Freeboard" tends to compensate for the many unknown factors that could contribute to flood heights greater than the height calculated for a selected size flood and floodway conditions, such as wave action, bridge openings, and the hydrological effect of urbanization of the watershed. Highest adjacent grade means the highest natural elevation of the ground surface, prior to construction, adjacent to the proposed foundation of a building. Historic structure means any structure that is: (1) Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places (a listing maintained by the U.S. Department of Interior) or preliminarily determined by the secretary of the interior as meeting the requirements for individual listing on the National Register; (2) Certified or preliminarily determined by the secretary of the interior as contributing to the historical significance of a registered historic district or a district preliminarily determined by the secretary to qualify as a registered historic district; (3) Individually listed on a state inventory of historic places and determined as eligible by states with historic preservation programs which have been approved by the secretary of the interior; or (4) Individually listed on a local inventory of historic places and determined as eligible by communities with historic preservation programs that have been certified either: a. By an approved state program as determined by the secretary of the interior, or b. Directly by the secretary of the interior in states without approved programs. Lowest floor means the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area, including basement. An unfinished or flood resistant enclosure, used solely for parking vehicles, building access, or storage, in an area other than a basement, is not considered a building's lowest floor, provided that such enclosure is not built so as to render the structure in violation of other provisions of this code. Manufactured home means a building, transportable in one or more sections, built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. The term also includes park trailers, travel trailers, and similar transportable structures placed on a site for 180 consecutive days or longer and intended to be improved property. Mean sea level means the average height of the sea for all stages of the tide. It is used as a reference for establishing various elevations within the floodplain. For purposes of this chapter, the term is synonymous with National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD). National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD) as corrected in 1929 is a vertical control used as a reference for establishing varying elevations within the floodplain. New construction means any structure for which the "start of construction" commenced on or after April 27, 1988 and includes any subsequent improvements to the structure (i.e., the effective date of the first floodplain management ordinance adopted by the community as a basis for community participation in the (NFIP)). New manufactured home park or subdivision means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed on or after April 27, 1988 (i.e., the effective date of the first floodplain management regulations adopted by a community). North American Vertical Datum (NAVD) as corrected in 1988 is a vertical control used as a reference for establishing varying elevations within the floodplain. Recreational vehicle means a vehicle, which is: (1) Built on a single chassis; (2) 400 square feet or less when measured at the largest horizontal projection; (3) Designed to be self-propelled or permanently tow able by a light duty truck; and (4) Designed primarily not for use as a permanent dwelling but as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel, or seasonal use. Start of construction means the date the development permit was issued, provided the actual start of construction repair, reconstruction, or improvement was within 180 days of the permit date. The actual start means the first placement of permanent construction of the structure such as the pouring of slabs or footings, installation of piles, construction columns, or any work beyond the stage of excavation, and includes the placement of a manufactured home on a foundation. Permanent construction does not include initial land preparation, such as clearing, grading and filling; nor does it include the installation of streets and/or walkways; nor does it include excavation for a basement, footings, piers or foundations or the erection of temporary forms; nor does it include the installation on the property of buildings appurtenant to the permitted structure, such as garages or sheds not occupied as dwellings units or part of the main structure (note: accessory structures are not exempt from any chapter requirements).
